description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

actual.value:
![ "WUR logo"](blob:https://rsr.akvo.org/8c8b0fe0-d49c-478c-b153-fc63905e48ab)
Report TMT Tunisia
On-line Tailor-Made Training (TMT) Course
Application of Genomic plant breeding for challenging climate change in Tunisia
4 October-10 December 2021
Summary The importance and utilization of genomic plant breeding technology and bioinformatics in relation is addressed. During the TMT course, participants got familiar with the following technologies that enable them to utilize it in their daily activities. This includes, Phenotyping and genotyping technology, Genomic sequencing technology, genomic assembly, Genetic approaches for discovering novel alleles for crop improvement, GWAS, SNPs, genomic assembly, and data base search Case studies of genomic as potato, tomato, and wheat, sharing experiences with resouarce persons. During the course, exercises using software programs /assignments/action plan/case studies
Resource persons at national and international level were engaged to share their experiences with the participants whereby two experts from the international Centre of maize and wheat (CIMMYT) in Mexico were invited to share their experiences in genomic selection and traits discovery.
Based on the new development and knowledge gained during the TMT, the participants were enabled to develop action plan on the most important crops in Tunisia which is expected to be implemented at their place of work.
Collaborating partners
Wageningen University & Research (WUR)-Plant Breeding (The Netherlands)
The Regional Field Crops Research Centre of Beja (CRRGC) in Tunisia-Beja (Ministry of Agriculture-IRESA)
Objectives of the course
Upgrading skills and know–how on the use and application of genomic plant breeding
Familiarize participants and update knowledge on the application of Bioinformatics, data management and analysis
Programme and content of the course
Module 1. Use and application of genomic plant breeding for improved traits.
This module is proposed to help the participants getting access to most modern plant breeding technology and tools that contribute towards improving their efficiency (in terms of time, cost and reliability) in developing new varieties in food crops that are having the desired traits. The described topics are mentioned below and will be addressed in one week as follows:
1. Modern sequencing techniques, importance of the genetic variation in the breeding program
2. Use of molecular tools in genotyping, mapping populations, marker system, phenotyping the individuals of the mapping populations, linkage analysis, and quantitative loci analysis.
3. Characterization of genetic resources using molecular tools
4. Identification of specific markers, identification of microsatellite sequences in plant genome
5. Introduction and assignments on using CAPS (Cleaved Amplified Polymorphic Sequences), SCARs (Sequence Characterized Amplified Regions) and KASPar genotyping.
Module 2. Use and application of Bioinformatics in data management and analysis
This module commences with basic training in database management, computer programming and training in elementary bioinformatics tools aimed at using existing software to collect, analyse and interpret DNA and protein sequence information and moves on to more open challenges. Assignments with case studies are implemented during the course. It is worth noting that WUR-Plant Breeding has developed several software programs which can be used as open source. during the course, participants are familiarized with the existing software which can serve their purposes.
Approach and methodology used
The online training course is self-study course whereby the teaching materials are made available online to the participants. In addition, teaching materials are complemented with assignments, literature, case studies, videos and interactive sessions. The selected participants will be able login with a personal account and subsequently can follow the course at their available time. After completing the course, evaluation is carried out and certificate of participation is issued.
Target audience
The target audience is consisting of plant breeders, researchers, docents, agronomists, plant pathologists, biotechnologists and plant physiologists at BSc, MSc and PhD level who are working and involved with the above-mentioned topics.
Trainers involved
Dr. Sjaak van Heusden (Trainer-WUR-Plant breeding)
Dr. Christian Bachem (Trainer and genomic expert)
Dr. Judith Risse (Biometrician , WUR)
Dr. Sarrah Ben M’Barek ( Coordinator IRESA)
Ing. Angela Machacilla (facilitator-WUR)
Dr. Daniel Danial (Team leader training & coordinator-WUR Plant breeding)
Resource persons
Dr. Sonia Hamza, INAT, Tunisia
Title: Genomics applied for population structure and QTL identification of old local durum wheat
Dr. Ines Yacoubi, Centre de Biotechnology de Sfax, Tunisia
Title: From annotated gene to potential molecular marker for abiotic stress tolerance in wheat
Example of Abscisic acid, stress, ripening proteins (ASR)
Dr. Deepmala Sehgal -CIMMYT, India-México
Association genetics, Apowerful approach to discover novel alleles for crop improvement
Julia Philomin, The use of bioinformatics in plant breeding , CIMMYT, Indi-Mexico
Number of participants who successfully complete the course:
A total of 24 participants have completed the course consisting of 15 females and 9 males.
Outcome
Participants are familiar with the molecular techniques that enables the participants to develop food crop varieties inefficient and effective way.
Participants were enabled to develop action plan that can be used at their working place
Participants got exposed to International and local experiences in modern plant breeding
Gaining experiences through assignments by using software in bioinformatics
Sustainability
Links are established between the trainers and participants whereby several academic and projects are expected to take place whereby the trainers can provide the required know-how.
Room for improvement Practical work in lab is missing due to Covid-19 More time is required for exercises in data base software ( Galaxy and Syntheny) Present concrete example of sequencing to understand the assembly techniques. , Include more videos and increase number of hours of the course More case studies on sequencing technology and molecular breeding
Recommnedations Implementing interactive Online quiz Needs for enhancing capacity building in management of genetic resources And design of plant bereding program especially in forest and semi forest crops, melon, palm, figs and faba beans Implement future courses after summer holiday and in the morning Need for practical work in field and lab Improve interaction between trainers and participants through face-to-face training Visits to laboratory and getting familiar with the new equipment’s and technology in Holland. Addressing technology on Molecular finger printing and traits mapping
Follow up Nuffic and OKP priorities /training Nuffic alumni opportunities ( scholarship, refresher course, short courses in NL (CDI, TMT, TMT+, collaborative research program, MSc and PhDs) Country plan of implementation Proirity is focused on food security , ecnomnmic growth and creating job opportuinties
_Dr. Ir. Daniel Danial_
_Team Leader Capacity Building in Plant Breeding & Biotechnology_
_Wageningen University and Research (WUR)-Plant Breeding_
_P.O. Box 386, 6700 AJ Wageningen, The Netherlands_
_Tel: +31-(0) 6-57875397_

actual.value:
1. Participants got familiar with the following technologies that enable them to utilize it in their daily activities. This includes, Phenotyping and genotyping technology, Genomic sequencing technology, genomic assembly, Genetic approaches for discovering novel alleles for crop improvement, GWAS, SNPs, genomic assembly, and data base search 2. Case studies of genomic as potato, tomato, and wheat, sharing experiences with resouarce persons. During the course, exercises using software programs /assignments/action plan/case studies
3. Resource persons at national and international level were engaged to share their experiences with the participants whereby two experts from the international Centre of maize and wheat (CIMMYT) in Mexico were invited to share their experiences in genomic selection and traits discovery.
4, Based on the new development and knowledge gained during the TMT, the participants were enabled to develop action plan on the most important crops in Tunisia which is expected to be implemented at their place of work.
